title: What Summer Hits Teach Brands About Emotional Power
description: Music, movies, and books have mastered the art of capturing summer vibes. You can, too.
author: Adam Hanft
excerpt: Learn the psychology of summer, the five characteristics of successful summer hits, and how to apply them to opportunities for marketers.
text: Just as summer ignites your urge to escape reality, the news cycles of summer 2025 inspire you to vanish and never return. Of course, summer as a time of lightness and unburdening has always been a psychological truth. It’s a deep imprint that goes back to the end of school, homework, and classroom imprisonment. Hollywood formally embraced this opportunity 50 years ago, as Jaws was the first summer blockbuster, and the notion of summer as a marketing window quickly spread to music and publishing. The “Song of the Summer” is a media brand, going back to the ‘70s as Rolling Stone notes. Summer is the most emotional and id-driven season. People don’t just consume, they feel. They want to be swept away and distracted. It is beneficial to deconstruct what these disparate yet universally effective cultural artifacts—movies, books, songs—have in common, as media properties. Then, it’s worth exploring how brands can tap into their heat, their hooks, and their half-life.   The opportunities brands have to own summer have never been greater, given the immediacy of social media. Also, don’t forget the ability of AI to quickly generate gorgeous and relatable content.  Here are five hot and happy opportunities. The illusion of effortlessness Summer success isn’t about the best movie, music, or novel. It’s about the most frictionless and the most fun. There should be no barrier to entry. This isn’t the season for complexity and the exhausting intellectual work that movies like Oppenheimer require. Songs of the summer hook quickly, reward repeat listening, and adapt to every setting: beach party, road trip, rooftop bar. Same with beach reads and blockbusters. They’re engineered for flow. Light enough to float and provocative enough to hold attention. For brands that means: Focus on immediately accessible messages and storytelling. Build emotional glide paths. These are narratives that create instant fun and joy in a season of stress without cognitive labor. Simplify your storytelling to its most basic and most primal levels. Make your brand a page-turner that fastens to the brain from the first sentence. The power of rhythmic structure Beach reads have a romantic arc. Summer movies follow a save-the-day trajectory. Hit songs have a chorus you recognize by the second listen. This is ritualized storytelling. The human brain craves it during the summer. It’s when people seek comfort, not challenge. People want to live in the moment and not a second beyond. For brands that means: Build a brain-craving structure into your creative, whether that’s a YouTube video or Instagram reels. Create consumer comfort with marketing rhythms and tropes that can be anticipated with recognizable familiarity. Think of it as creating loop-friendly, design experiences that reward repetition. Ask yourself if your creativity allows consumers to hum along, literally or metaphorically with your brand. Summer heat feels different A summer hit is instantly recognizable. One frame of a James Cameron movie, one cover of an Elin Hilderbrand novel, one synth drop in a Dua Lipa song is a signal that fits an established pattern. Summer isn’t subtle. It’s a season of bold aesthetics—high saturation, simple motifs, and emotional immediacy. For brands that means: Have the courage to invent a new summer language for your brand that is instantly recognizable. Don’t worry about diverting from your core story. Summer is a time you don’t need to beg for permission to change. It is important to make that story yours and yours alone. Don’t swipe through existing memes. Instead, create immediate aesthetic stickiness that consumers can remix themselves.   Summer makes everyone part of the creator economy And if you can, craft seasonal identities: limited-edition packaging, summer mode UI, curated playlists. Summer is a countdown What gives the song of the summer its power isn’t just that it’s good. It’s that it won’t last. Everyone knows autumn is inevitable, and of course, people want to delay it. Summer hits have built-in urgency and can help you forget that tomorrow will indeed come. Humans must accept the immutability of a finite shelf life. However, there is no doubt that we will look back nostalgically on the summer experience of a song whenever a few notes drift onto personal radar.  The same goes for beach reads and blockbusters: They dominate a fleeting cultural moment. Scarcity, combined with emotional resonance, creates a kind of psychic FOMO.  For brands that means: Treat summer like a limited-edition campaign window, not a minor variant. Create time-bound participatory mechanics. This means creating rituals with expiration dates. Think: sunset-only offers, timed playlists, drip countdowns, flavor-of-the-month collabs. Also, remember to communicate with empathy. Every one of your consumers mourns the shortness of summer. Share it with them. The days are longer. The nights are filled with buzz and booze (and increasingly, alcohol-free cocktails). Those are the conditions for the epidemic spread of smartly manufactured summer artifacts. Every summer hit becomes an immediate part of a shared language. You sing it, quote it, and caption your photo with it. It’s a meme vector and a mirror. For brands that means: You can capitalize on summer with brand campaigns built for public consumption and sharing that are quotable and remixable. It’s the season when people are driven to post, wear, and share. Marketers need to think in terms of collective vibes and co-creation. Don’t think “this is our ad,” but “this is your summer anthem, brought to you by us.” In the end, summer hits aren’t just about capturing attention. They’re about temporal framing, about capturing a feeling, and letting people experience it immersively and repeatedly.  Brands that master the mechanics of summer seduction build stronger connections for the rest of year. Like the song that defines a summer, they’ll be replayed in people’s heads, long after the brutal reality of life-as-usual and the grimness of the news cycle reasserts itself. The opinions expressed here by Inc.com columnists are their own, not those of Inc.com.The early-rate deadline for the 2025 Inc. html:
Just as summer ignites your urge to escape reality, the news cycles of summer 2025 inspire you to vanish and never return. Of course, summer as a time of lightness and unburdening has always been a psychological truth. It’s a deep imprint that goes back to the end of school, homework, and classroom imprisonment. 

Hollywood formally embraced this opportunity 50 years ago, as Jaws was the first summer blockbuster, and the notion of summer as a marketing window quickly spread to music and publishing. The “Song of the Summer” is a media brand, going back to the ‘70s as Rolling Stone notes. 

Summer is the most emotional and id-driven season. People don’t just consume, they feel. They want to be swept away and distracted. It is beneficial to deconstruct what these disparate yet universally effective cultural artifacts—movies, books, songs—have in common, as media properties. Then, it’s worth exploring how brands can tap into their heat, their hooks, and their half-life.   

The opportunities brands have to own summer have never been greater, given the immediacy of social media. Also, don’t forget the ability of AI to quickly generate gorgeous and relatable content.  

Here are five hot and happy opportunities. 

The illusion of effortlessness 

Summer success isn’t about the best movie, music, or novel. It’s about the most frictionless and the most fun. There should be no barrier to entry. This isn’t the season for complexity and the exhausting intellectual work that movies like Oppenheimer require. 

Songs of the summer hook quickly, reward repeat listening, and adapt to every setting: beach party, road trip, rooftop bar. Same with beach reads and blockbusters. They’re engineered for flow. Light enough to float and provocative enough to hold attention. 

For brands that means: Focus on immediately accessible messages and storytelling. Build emotional glide paths. These are narratives that create instant fun and joy in a season of stress without cognitive labor. 

Simplify your storytelling to its most basic and most primal levels. Make your brand a page-turner that fastens to the brain from the first sentence. 

The power of rhythmic structure 

Beach reads have a romantic arc. Summer movies follow a save-the-day trajectory. Hit songs have a chorus you recognize by the second listen. This is ritualized storytelling. The human brain craves it during the summer. It’s when people seek comfort, not challenge. People want to live in the moment and not a second beyond. 

For brands that means: Build a brain-craving structure into your creative, whether that’s a YouTube video or Instagram reels. Create consumer comfort with marketing rhythms and tropes that can be anticipated with recognizable familiarity. 

Think of it as creating loop-friendly, design experiences that reward repetition. Ask yourself if your creativity allows consumers to hum along, literally or metaphorically with your brand. 

Summer heat feels different 

A summer hit is instantly recognizable. One frame of a James Cameron movie, one cover of an Elin Hilderbrand novel, one synth drop in a Dua Lipa song is a signal that fits an established pattern. Summer isn’t subtle. It’s a season of bold aesthetics—high saturation, simple motifs, and emotional immediacy. 

For brands that means: Have the courage to invent a new summer language for your brand that is instantly recognizable. Don’t worry about diverting from your core story. Summer is a time you don’t need to beg for permission to change. 

It is important to make that story yours and yours alone. Don’t swipe through existing memes. Instead, create immediate aesthetic stickiness that consumers can remix themselves.   

Summer makes everyone part of the creator economy And if you can, craft seasonal identities: limited-edition packaging, summer mode UI, curated playlists. 

Summer is a countdown 

What gives the song of the summer its power isn’t just that it’s good. It’s that it won’t last. Everyone knows autumn is inevitable, and of course, people want to delay it. Summer hits have built-in urgency and can help you forget that tomorrow will indeed come. 

Humans must accept the immutability of a finite shelf life. However, there is no doubt that we will look back nostalgically on the summer experience of a song whenever a few notes drift onto personal radar.  

The same goes for beach reads and blockbusters: They dominate a fleeting cultural moment. Scarcity, combined with emotional resonance, creates a kind of psychic FOMO.  

For brands that means: Treat summer like a limited-edition campaign window, not a minor variant. Create time-bound participatory mechanics. This means creating rituals with expiration dates. Think: sunset-only offers, timed playlists, drip countdowns, flavor-of-the-month collabs. 

Also, remember to communicate with empathy. Every one of your consumers mourns the shortness of summer. Share it with them. 

The days are longer. The nights are filled with buzz and booze (and increasingly, alcohol-free cocktails). Those are the conditions for the epidemic spread of smartly manufactured summer artifacts. Every summer hit becomes an immediate part of a shared language. You sing it, quote it, and caption your photo with it. It’s a meme vector and a mirror. 

For brands that means: You can capitalize on summer with brand campaigns built for public consumption and sharing that are quotable and remixable. It’s the season when people are driven to post, wear, and share. 

Marketers need to think in terms of collective vibes and co-creation. Don’t think “this is our ad,” but “this is your summer anthem, brought to you by us.” 

In the end, summer hits aren’t just about capturing attention. They’re about temporal framing, about capturing a feeling, and letting people experience it immersively and repeatedly.  

Brands that master the mechanics of summer seduction build stronger connections for the rest of year. Like the song that defines a summer, they’ll be replayed in people’s heads, long after the brutal reality of life-as-usual and the grimness of the news cycle reasserts itself.
